description: From Middle English frightful (“afraid”), from Old English forhtful (“fainthearted, timorous”). Equivalent to fright +‎ -ful.

adjectives.description: frightful (comparative more frightful, superlative most frightful)

examples: Ðis frigtful ðus a-biden,Quiles ðis daiȝes for ben gliden.

definitionGroups.group: Full of something causing fright, whether

entries.meaning: (hyperbolic) Unpleasant, dreadful, awful (also used as an intensifier).
examples: Francis Urquhart: What a frightful little man. Where do they find them these days?Tim Stamper: God knows. If I had a dog like that, I'd shoot it.Francis Urquhart: Well, yes. Quite.

adverbs.description: frightful (comparative more frightful, superlative most frightful)
